title: Desalination: Drinking the Ocean
description: A quick win: understand Desalination: Drinking the Ocean.

hook.text: 97% of Earth's water is salty. Desalination turns seawater drinkable, but energy costs kept it priceyâ€”until now.

buildup.text: Reverse osmosis forces seawater through membranes with pores so tiny only water passes. Salt stays behind.

discovery.text: Energy needs have fallen 90% since the 1970s. Modern plants make drinking water for $0.50-$1.00 per cubic meter.

twist.text: Leftover brine is twice as salty as seawater. Dumping it into the ocean kills marine life near the discharge point.

climax.text: Israel gets 80% of its drinking water from desalination. Saudi Arabia, Australia, and Singapore follow the same path.

punchline.text: We're surrounded by water we can finally afford to drink.

quiz.question: What environmental concern does desalination create?
options: Concentrated brine discharge kills marine life near the outflow point
The membranes release microplastics into drinking water
Desalination plants consume more energy than the water they produce
